author: RoyTinker
body: Please allow installation on macOS via `brew cask install powershell` without requiring a password during the install. I just read that PowerShell is available on macOS. How cool! But after typing `brew cask install powershell`, I was greeted with a `Password:` prompt: I have _never_ had a homebrew package ask me for my password. (I currently have about 60 packages installed.) This makes me feel really uncomfortable... I've decided not to install it after all.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: @TravisEz13 Could you please comment the request?

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body:
We use a pkg to install a shell.  This will require sudo access.  **As it says two lines above**

Please use the tar.gz instructions.

```
# Download the powershell '.tar.gz' archive
curl -L -o /tmp/powershell.tar.gz https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases/download/v6.2.0/powershell-6.2.0-osx-x64.tar.gz

# Create the target folder where powershell will be placed
mkdir -p <yourPath>

# Expand powershell to the target folder
tar zxf /tmp/powershell.tar.gz -C <yourPath>

# Set execute permissions
chmod +x <yourPath>/pwsh
```

comments.author: RoyTinker
comments.body:
> We use a pkg to install a shell. This will require sudo access. __As it says two lines above__

I didn't miss the note two lines above. But saying "I'm going to ask for your password" two lines before a `Password:` prompt doesn't ease the discomfort.

My point in filing this issue is to document--on behalf of many macOS users--what may be keeping them from pursuing a casual interest in `pwsh` on their computers, and suggest developing a less imposing installation process.

comments.author: RoyTinker
comments.body:
Could you please remove the `Issue-Question` and `Resolution-Answered` tags?

I realize I wasn't clear. I intended this as an enhancement request, not a question. Thanks for providing a workaround, but the issue I wanted to raise is that `homebrew` packages never ask for passwords, and they install all sorts of things, from `node` and `ruby` to `cowsay` and everything in between -- always without requiring a password.

To fully support `homebrew` as a distribution channel, I believe `pwsh` would do best not to deviate from that expectation.

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body:
This is not possible for this type of package.  You would need to ask Apple to allow packages that modify system state to do so without requiring a password.  I would not recommend that they allow that.  As homebrew clearly states, we are allowed to prompt for a password.

You could submit your own 'powershell-limited' package, to the casks repo, without the additional features that does not function as a shell.

Additionally, this is homebrew maintained code.  Not, code maintained by us.

comments.author: RoyTinker
comments.body:
OK, looks like the issue is really that a MacOS installer .pkg is being used to install PowerShell even from HomeBrew. Installer packages use the macOS installer infrastructure, which requires authentication. https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-cask/blob/master/Casks/powershell.rb I understand that homebrew doesn't disallow asking for a password. But it strongly preaches "don't run `brew` as root!" and 99% of packages (including all shells, as far as I know - I tried `zsh`, `fish`, `bash`, `ksh`, `tcsh`) don't require a password during installation.

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body:
@RoyTinker 	You don't run homebrew as root.  Homebrew will prompt for a password, as it states in the repro you gave us.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10873629/64658662-171d0b00-d3ed-11e9-819b-3b7d49a169d6.png)

Someone could try to write a Formulae, which would solve your issue, but if it was done, unfortunately, it would not be supported by Microsoft, as it would be a product we did not build.  Our guidance would remain to use the cask, which will prompt for password.

Feel free to contribute a formula to **homebrew** or file an issue in the **homebrew** repo for a formula to be created.
